721765f-b.text:
Mott Street, east side, south from but not including Canal, to and including Bayard Streets. The view shows Public School No. 108 at Nos. 60-64 Mott Street.

June 9, 1933.

P. L. Sperr

The structure seen at the left (No. 66 Mott Street) has been sold by the Lafayette National Bank and will be modernized at a cost of $15,000 according to the new York Times of October 13, 1938 . It will then be rented to Chinese concerns for the purpose of merchandise display, in anticipation of World's Fair visitors to this locality.

721768f-b.text:
(1 a 2)
85 to 69 Mott Street, at, adjoining and south of the S. W. corner of Canal Street (right), showing prominently two old 3 story structures directly at the corner. These bear No's. 85 &: 83, and have been the property of George Bull ( owner of Saratoga race track) and Albert W. )aclay since 1836. The vacant 1ot seen to the rear of same is a portion of this plotage (76.6 x 50.6) and will shortly be improved with a one story addition, as per View No. 2. The New York Times, of March 11, 1939, reports the lease of this site to the Low Cost Housing Corporation for a period of 51 years, same being negotiated by Joseph P. Day. The present buildings, said to have been erected about 150 years ago, will be razed and a two-story
store and office building erected on the site.
Ho. 1 1922.
Lugene L. Armbruster Collection No. 2 June, 1929.
721768f-b.folder: Mott Street & Canal Street, Manhattan, NY

107 Mott Street, west side, between Canal and Hester Streets. Building referred to is a 3-story frame house with a brick front.

1932.
